ditch.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: a long narrow hole dug at the side of a field, road etc to hold or remove unwanted water
ditch.translation[0].note_box[0].section: The car had become stuck in a deep ditch.
They were digging a drainage ditch.
The fields were separated by irrigation ditches.
The horse had to jump over an open ditch.
His clothes were found in a roadside ditch.
Ditches were dug to prevent the river from flooding.
a ditch runs along/down etc something
A muddy ditch ran along the side of the field.
ditch.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to stop having something because you no longer want it
ditch.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The government has ditched plans to privatise the prison.
ditch.translation[1].definitions[1].defi: to end a romantic relationship with someone
ditch.translation[1].definitions[1].exam: Meg and Neil were due to marry, but she ditched him.
ditch.translation[1].definitions[2].defi: to not go to school, a class etc when you should
ditch.translation[1].definitions[3].defi: to leave someone you are with in a place without telling them you are going
ditch.translation[1].definitions[4].defi: to land an aircraft in a controlled crash into water
ditch.translation[1].definitions[4].exam: Two balloonists had to ditch during the race.
